titleStmt.title: P.Math. leaf C recto, Mathematical Problem c1 Revisited: Another New Algorithm

encodingDesc.ab: Converted from a Word document for Pylon.

docTitle.titlePart: P.Math. leaf C recto, Mathematical Problem c1 Revisited: Another New Algorithm

div.p:
Mathematical problem c1 in P.Math. (Oxyrhynchos? 350â€“375; TM 92734) was interpreted in the ed.pr. as being concerned with finding the volume of a quadrangular prism, an interpretation that accounted well for the preserved computations.
I am grateful to Alexander Jones for commenting on a draft of this paper and to both editors for kindly sharing the image of the relevant codex page with me. I am also grateful to the anonymous owner of the â€œArchimedes Palimpsestâ€ for permission to reproduce it. The statement of the problem, however, was far from clear. Here is how it appears in the edition:

The editors were puzzled by the reference to â€˜leavesâ€™ in line 4 (Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Ï‰Î½) and the incomprehensible Î±Ì£Ï€Ì£Î¿Ì£ÏÌ£Î¹Ì£ in line 3. The latter characters in fact are very clearly visible, while the traces in line 2 printed in the edition as Ì£[ Ì£ Ì£] Ì£ÏÎ¹ Ì£Î¿Î¹ suggest that something similar was written there, too (Fig. 1). The appearance of the sequence Î±Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¹ along with Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Ï‰Î½ in the description of a piece of timber makes it virtually certain that it conceals a reference to the lower part of a tree, from the root(s), á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Î¯Î¶Î·Ï‚ or á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Î¹Î¶á¿¶Î½, as opposed to its upper part, from the foliage, á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Ï‰Î½. The terminology comes up in a passage of Theophrastus in which he explains how wood should be chosen for sockets and pivots (HP 5.3.7): Î Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Î´á½² Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼”Î¼Ï€Î±Î»Î¹Î½ Ï„Î¹Î¸Î­Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½° Î¾ÏÎ»Î± Ï„ÏŒ Ï„Îµ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¿¥Î¯Î¶Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Î¿Ï…. ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Î´á½² Î¿á¼± Ï„Î­ÎºÏ„Î¿Î½ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½¸ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Î¿Ï… Ï„á½¸ á¼„Î½Ï‰, â€œThey make them (sc. hinges) by reversing the wood â€˜from the rootâ€™ and â€˜from the foliageâ€™â€”by â€˜wood from the foliageâ€™ they mean the upper part wood.â€

That the terminology in the statement of c1 indeed refers to the â€˜lowerâ€™ and â€˜upperâ€™ ends of the original tree is further supported by the measurements of the timber because the dimensions of the cross-section â€˜from the rootâ€™ (16 by 8 fingers) are larger than those â€˜from the foliageâ€™ (12 by 6 fingers). References to the lower and upper ends of the timber in the statement of the problem, however, entail a reconsideration of the shape of the object and of the algorithm used for computing its volume. The description corresponds not to a quadrangular prism, but to a truncated pyramid with a rectangular base 18 by 8 fingers, a rectangular top 12 by 6 fingers, and a â€˜lengthâ€™, which is presumably its height, of 28 cubits. It can be illustrated with the following diagram (Fig. 2), in which no attempt is made to render the height commensurate with the dimensions of the base and of the top (one should imagine the figure in the diagram stretched out along its vertical dimension so that its height is about 40 times its width at the base):

The volume of this truncated pyramid is computed as if it were a rectangular prism of the given height (h) with the sides of its bottom face equaling the average of the corresponding sides of the base and of the top:

The algorithm of course produces an approximation and underestimates the volume of the object. Notably, a similar algorithm (S3A) is used in P.Math. in problem n1, in which the volume of a conic frustum is computed as if it were a cylinder with the diameter equaling the average of the lower and upper diameters.
For the algorithm, cf. Bagnall and Jones (2019): 42-43; the algorithm S3B, not used in P.Math. but well attested elsewhere, computes the volume of a conic frustum as if for a cylinder with a circumference equaling the average of the lower and upper circumferences.
The new algorithm can now be added to Bagnall and Jonesâ€™ collection of algorithms:
S6C. Pyramidal frustum volume algorithm C (approximate).
Given a pyramidal frustum having rectangular base with sides a and b, rectangular top with sides a and b, and height h, find the volume V:

The computations of the volume in the solution of the problem c1 are followed by the conversion of the productâ€”the interim resultâ€”to volumetric cubits and fingers. The conversion factors 288 and 12 indicate that the unnamed units in which the final result is expressed are the 3-palm cubit and its fingers.
For volume cubits of different sizes used for expressing volume of wood, and for computation of volume, cf. Lougovaya (2022).

There remains a question of the description of the wood as Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½ Î½Î­Î¿Î½ in the statement of the problem. The adjective might simply mean â€˜youngâ€™, designating timber that came from a younger as opposed to an older tree. But it is tempting to see in Î½Î­Î¿Î½ a misspelling of Î½Îµá¿–Î¿Î½, which Aelius Herodianus defines as Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î½Î·á½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ï€Ï…Î¸Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿ÎµÎ¹Î´á½²Ï‚ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½, â€˜the keel wood of the shipâ€™ (De prosod. catholica, 3,1, p. 356). Hesychius and Photius use the word in the plural and explain it more vaguely as ship-timber (Hesych., s.v. Î½Îµá¿–Î±Â· Î¾ÏÎ»Î±, Ï„á½° Îµá¼°Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½´Î½ Î½Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Î®Î´ÎµÎ¹Î±, â€˜wood suitable for building shipsâ€™; Photius, s.v. Î½Îµá¿–Î±: Ï„á½° Îµá¼°Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½´Î½ Î½Îµá¿¶Î½ Î¾ÏÎ»Î±, â€˜wood for building shipsâ€™). The change ÎµÎ¹>Îµ is relatively common, especially before the back vowel â€˜oâ€™, and occurs elsewhere in P.Math.
Cf. Gignac (1976):257, Bagnall and Jones (2019):12. If this is the word meant, the object in the problem is ship-timber, and since it is rectangular in cross-section, perhaps the keel or floor of the hull was envisaged rather than a mast.

note.p: 2 á¿¥á½·Î³Ì£Î¿Î¹: it is difficult to decide from the image whether the letter after the first iota is gamma or tau, as its horizontal protrudes slightly to the left. It is certainly not a zeta, cf. also 3n.

3 á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥Î¹<Î¶-> Î´Î±ÎºÏ„ÏÌ£[Î»Ï‰Î½]: the delta of Î´Î±ÎºÏ„ÏÌ£[Î»Ï‰Î½] is corrected from what seems to have been a gamma; perhaps the scribe started writing á¿¥Î¹Î³-, as in line 2, but then corrected the gamma to the delta of the subsequent word. There seems to be no sign of an abbreviation, and the phonetic process that could have produced the interchange of Î³ (or Ï„) with Î¶ is not immediately clear, yet it is hardly possibly that a different word but á¿¥á½·Î¶Î·, in whatever form, was meant here and in line 2.

4-5 One would expect Îµá½‘ÏÎµá¿–Î½ at the end of line 4 to be followed by Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµá½¸Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Ï…, cf. the formulation of the task in another volume problem, g3 (G verso, lines 11-12), Îµá½‘ÏÎµá¿–Î½ | [Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ„]ÎµÏÎµÏŒÎ½, â€˜find the volumeâ€™, or in similar problems in Didymus, Mensurae marmorum ac lignorum 40 and 41 (Heiberg), Îµá½‘ÏÎµá¿–Î½ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµÏŒÎ½, â€˜to find its volumeâ€™. That Ï„á½¸ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½ stands in the nominative and not the genitive, would not be a problem in P.Math., which has multiple instances of the wrong usage of cases,
Bagnall and Jones (2019): 14 provide a useful list of wrongly used cases and other syntactical flaws in the codex. but Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµÏŒÎ½ is certainly too long for the lacuna. Two possibilities suggest themselves: The word for volume may have been written without the article, thus Îµá½‘ÏÎµá¿–Î½ | [ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµá½¸Î½] Ï„á½¸ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½, l. Îµá½‘ÏÎµá¿–Î½ | [ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµá½¸Î½] Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿á¿¦. Or, a different expression was used for the question about the size of the piece, such as [Ï€á½¹ÏƒÏ‰Î½] Ï„á½¸ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½, â€˜how big is the wood?â€™ where Ï€á½¹ÏƒÏ‰Î½ would imply Ï€á½¹ÏƒÏ‰Î½ Ï€Î·Ï‡á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎµá¿¶Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï„á½¸ Î¾ÏÎ»Î¿Î½, â€˜of how many volume cubits is the wood?â€™ Since volume units are not named in problems of this type in P.Math. (that is, a3, b5, c1 and g4), it is likely that Ï€á½¹ÏƒÏ‰Î½ would not be followed by the word designating units either.

7 {Î¹Ì…}Ï›Ì…: I follow the editors in printing and excising the iota, although the squiggle to the left of the stigma does not really look like an iota. It could be that the writer initially miscopied from his original (cf. the omicron in Ï„á½¹ earlier in the line, which clearly was first written as a beta with a numeral overstroke). For example, he might have begun to write kappa before switching to stigma, but without caring to delete the left vertical of the kappa. Whatever its genesis, this stroke ought to be excised.

Gignac, F.T. (1976) A Grammar of the Greek Papyri of the Roman and Byzantine Periods. I. Phonology., (Milano Goliardica 1976).
Lougovaya, J. (2022) "On Cubic and Other Volumetric Cubits and Fingers," Pylon 1.

sourceDesc.p: The contents of this document are generated from SOSOL.

div.p: â€˜A piece of ship (?) timber, 28 cubits; width from the roots 16 fingers, from the foliage 12 fingers; thickness from the roots 8 fingers, from the foliage 6 fingers. Find [how big?] is the timber. I do it this way: I add the width, 16 and 12, the result is 28, half of which is 14. I add the thickness, 6 and 8, the result is 14, half of which is 7. (Multiply) by 14, the result is 98. (Multiply) by the length of 28 cubits, the result is 2,744. This I divide by 288 and the remainder into fingers, (divide by) 12, the result is 9 and 12 2/3 fingers. So it holds for similar cases. Diagram.â€™
